name: Earliest Map of Salford (Research Gap)
description: Salford received its borough charter in 1230 — 71 years before Manchester (1301) — and was the administrative centre of the Hundred of Salford covering all of southeast Lancashire. Yet no dedicated pre-1650 map of Salford is known to exist. This entry tracks the search for the earliest cartographic record of Salford town centre (Greengate area).
notes:
RESEARCH GAP: No dedicated map of Salford town centre is known before c.1650.

Salford's medieval core was at Greengate — market, Hundred Court, borough centre.
Borough charter: 1230 (Manchester's was 1301).
Hundred of Salford covered: Manchester, Bolton, Bury, Rochdale, Oldham, Middleton, Ashton.
Manor held by the Crown, later granted to various nobles.

Maps titled 'Manchester & Salford' mostly focus on Manchester's side:
- Source 25: Plan of Manchester & Salford (c.1650) — earliest, but Manchester-centric
- Source 9: Casson & Berry (1741) — shows both sides of Irwell, Salford secondary
- Source 11: Green (1787-94) — includes Salford but focus is Manchester

Gough Map (c.1360) does NOT show Salford despite it being a borough since 1230.
Speed's Lancashire (1610) shows Lancaster inset, not Salford.

Possible leads:
- Salford manorial court rolls (text, not maps)
- Lancashire Record Office — estate maps?
- Chetham's Library — any pre-1650 Salford material?
- Salford Local History Library (Salford Museum & Art Gallery)
- The National Archives — Crown manor records for Salford

This is a genuine cartographic blind spot — a 420-year borough with no known map.
